messageBody:
> >Well, true...but how you get away with not changing the SQL for long
> >periods is beyond me. I've never done serious develoment on a system
> >with a lot of database code where the database wasn't changing all the
> >time. But we probably just tend to work on different styles of
> projects.
>
> If I change the SQL statements, then I test the new statements as
> needed. That's why I put them in one place, to make them easier to test
> all at once and in isolation from the rest of the system.

Having read the last 20 or so messages on the subject I see a common theme:
Keep together what changes together. However, what changes together might be
completely different in different development scenarios. Two examples:
- If you are developing a new application and you have full control over the
DB schema, a change in the domain model will most probably entail a
corresponding (and easy to recognize) change in the schema and thus entail a change
in the SQL sattements. It then makes perfect sense IMO to keep domain code and
SQL close together (eg. in an inner class as suggested).
- If you develop an application on top of an existing database over which
you have no control you probably need a dedicated layer to map your objects
onto the RDBMS. Then the code in the three layers (domain, mapping, database)
will have different reasons for change, so it should be kept separately.

You're facing even more differences if you develop for 2,3 or 4 DBMS.
Moreover, the development scenario is likely to change one day, eg. as soon as the
application is in production you cannot change the schema easily any more.
This change of situation might force you to change your policy of where to put
your SQL.

My point in short: There's no single best way where to put the SQL.

Johannes
